key_title: Key to the species of Sclerolaena

breadcrumbs.key_title: Key to the main groups of plants in Victoria
Key to the families of Dicotyledons
Key to the genera of Chenopodiaceae

source.author: Walsh, N.G.
source.title: Chenopodiaceae
source.in_title: Flora of Victoria. Vol. 3. Dicotyledons Winteraceae to Myrtaceae
source.citation: Modified from: Walsh, N.G. (1996). Chenopodiaceae. In: Walsh, N.G.; Entwisle, T.J. (eds), Flora of Victoria. Vol. 3. Dicotyledons Winteraceae to Myrtaceae. Inkata Press, Melbourne.

leads.lead_text: Plant glabrous except axillary tufts of hairs
Plant variously hairy
Spines 6
Spines 3, 4 or 5
Leaves flat, linear to narrowly oblong or elliptic
Leaves terete to semi-terete, fleshy
Spines 3
Spines 4–5 (1 or 2 much shorter than others and sometimes obscure)
Spines 4 or 5 (3 prominent, 1 or 2 shorter); limb pubescent, exserted beyond spine-bases for 1–2 mm
Spines 4 (3 prominent, 1 shorter and often obscure); limb glabrous, not or barely exserted above spine-bases
2 of the 3 larger spines lateral in line, not curving around the branch, the third abaxial; stamens 3
The larger spines not in line laterally, 1 abaxial, 1 lateral, and 1 somewhat adaxial and curved around branch; stamens usually 5
Fruiting perianth hard, cup-shaped to subglobular with c. 11 short spines radiating from the truncate apex
Fruiting perianth not as above, with up to 6 spines
Spines 2
Spines 3–6
Fruiting perianth with prominently hollowed base; spines less than 3 mm long
Fruiting perianth not prominently hollowed at base; spines more than 4 mm long
Spines divergent, mostly c. 2 mm long
Spines erect and almost parallel, mostly 0.5–1 mm long
Fruiting perianth (except limb) glabrous; leaves glossy, with appressed, medifixed hairs
Fruiting perianth hairy; leaves with basifixed hairs
Stems remaining pubescent; spines 8–20 mm long, hairy for much of their length
Older stems becoming glabrous; spines less than 8 mm long, usually only hairy near base
Leaves remaining grey- or white-woolly with spreading, distinctly barbed or shortly branched hairs
Leaves glabrescent, or if remaining hairy, hairs, appressed, simple, smooth to scabridulous
Spines divergent and ascending in different vertical planes; hairs copious on tube; limb barely exserted beyond base of spines
Spines divergent, but ascending in same vertical plane; hairs sparse on tube; limb prominently exserted above base of spines
Spines 6 (if ever 5, then fruiting perianth more than 2 mm long)
Spines 3–5 (when 5, fruiting perianth less than 2 mm long)
Branches glabrous except for axillary hair tufts; fruit strongly 10-ribbed, produced at the base into 1 or 2 short spreading spurs, usually distinctly pink to red at maturity
Branches hairy between leaves; fruit not or only weakly ribbed, not produced into basal spurs, not or rarely reddish
Branches sparsely cottony; the 2 shorter, radicular spines unequal (1 sometimes suppressed)
Branches with short, appressed hairs; the 2 shorter, radicular spines subequal
Spines 5
Spines 3 or 4
Perianth densely woolly; longer spines 8–15 mm long
Perianth glabrous to minutely woolly; longer spines 5–10 mm long
Tube of fruiting perianth glabrous; hairs of leaves medifixed
Tube of fruiting perianth hairy; hairs basifixed
Tube of fruiting perianth turbinate, flattened
Tube of fruiting perianth cylindric or barrel-shaped
